headline: Real Homemade Bagels
description: A bagel recipe for that authentic bagel flavor and texture. Top them with coarse salt, sesame seeds, poppy seeds, onion flakes, or everything!

video.description: Learn how to make bagels right in your own kitchen.
video.name: Real Homemade Bagels

name: Real Homemade Bagels

recipeInstructions.text: Make bagels: Combine water, flour, sugar, salt, vegetable oil, and yeast in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the dough hook. Mix on low speed until dough is well-developed, about 8 minutes. To ensure the gluten has developed fully, cut off a walnut-sized piece of dough. Flour your fingers, and then stretch the dough: if it tears immediately, the dough needs more kneading. Fully developed dough should form a thin translucent "windowpane."
Transfer dough to a lightly oiled bowl, cover it with plastic wrap and a kitchen towel, and let rise for 2 hours.

Punch dough down, place it on a lightly floured work surface, and use a knife or dough scraper to divide the dough into 6 pieces (or more, for smaller bagels). Roll each piece of dough into a sausage shape about 6 inches long. Join the ends to form a circle. Repeat with the remaining dough, and let the bagels rest for 15 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 475 degrees F (245 degrees C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Arrange small plates with poppy seeds, sesame seeds, and onion flakes next to the baking sheet.

Bring 4 quarts of water to a boil in a large pot. Add honey, if desired (see Editor's Note). Boil three bagels at a time, until they rise to the surface of the pot, about 1 minute per side. Remove bagels with a slotted spoon and place them on the lined baking sheet.
Dip the tops of the wet bagels into the toppings and arrange them, seed-side up, on the baking sheet. Sprinkle with coarse salt, if desired.
Bake in the preheated oven until the bagels begin to brown, 15 to 20 minutes.

review.reviewBody: We made these last night, we made 12 bagels. They came out perfect, takes exactly like a NY bagel. I used agave instead of honey. I will not be buying bagels anymore!!

Love it! I am an experienced bread and bagel maker and was intrigued with this recipe because of the way you put the bagels together, in a log. I have made this recipe twice already this week and they are the best I have made, professional and taste amazing. I used half whole wheat in one batch. Thank you!
dough was dry hard ti handle

I used my bread machineâ€™s dough setting. Cutting the dough into sixths made the bagels huge, so after the first three, I cut thinner strips which still made them good size. Tasted like store bought.

Separating the dough to 6 is a bit silly. This makes for HUGE bagels. On a do over, I would separate the dough to 10 or 12. And leave out the parchment paper. The honey makes these VERY SWEET. Next time we will leave that out.
Awesome to be able to make them at home
Hell Yes !!!!!!!

Had to add a coupe of t water and remix another 5 min to get it to stretch properly but it did. Still got to cook it. Me be a newbe to this. First timer for Bagels I forgot to say that I went 1/2 the flour as semolina flour. Will see and hope it turns out well. Think I will let it set in fridge over night to help it develop.
I made plain whole wheat bagels & came out great. Needed to reduce the bake time only by a couple of mins. Otherwise perfect.
While there is the need to add a bit more water, the recipe is great. Rave reviews from family. Easiest and best tasting BIG 6 bagels ever-I actually made 8 normal size -Thanks for sharing!!
Made these 3 times now and been a success every time. Needed to add slightly more water than recipe recommended.

Love this recipe! It's quick and easy to make in one day. Also, have left shaped bagels in fridge overnight and comes out great too. My son asks me to make almost every day. The bagels are better than the chain store we used to frequently every day. Didn't change anything except make a ball and put thumb through to get consistent shape of bagels and a must to use honey.
Easy to make homemade bagels. I will be using this recipe again.

Yes the temperature in the oven turn it down to 450 For my oven 475 too high And baked for 13 minutes seems enough The bagels taste great for first time I will definitely try other toppings like butter

I love bagels and used to eat them wherever I travel, unfortunately couldnâ€™t find good bagels at my-home country. So I tried these with no changes and was so proud of the results. My daughter loved them with creamy cheese, avocado, lettuce and sun dried tomatoes. Thank you so much for the good recipe

Definitely not enough water in the dough, my KitchenAid stand mixer was struggling so I bumped it up to just shy of two cups and it worked beautifully. The dough came out perfect. Other than that issue everything else was great
Solid basic bagel recipe, bagels are just hard to make!

I have made these twice and followed the directions. One change that really helped was to firm the individual bagels into a ball, flatten then slightly, then punch the hole with your thumb. It's impossible to get the hole right with the log shaped dough pinched together.
Made this recipe, it was really good for homemade. I like onion bagels , so I chopped an onion added to the dough, and it was awesome.
Great recipe - first time making them and they were a BIG hit!
I think this would be better aimed for 8-12 bagels. The ones I ended up with were huge.
Very easy to follow. Loved it!! We didn't use all the flower, but over all turned out great and will be doing again.
It s great

Amazing recipe, they turn out great! However, could you please update this recipe with ingredients by weight? With that much flour, there are serious inconsistencies between using 520 and 590 grams (the range of weights of 4 1/2 cups) so it would help make the recipe spot on
I doubled the recipe so I could make more than six. These are fresh out of the oven. Made everything, plain, salt and cinnamon & sugar. Canâ€™t wait to try

Found this receipt and, of course, read the reviews. Made it with 4 cups flour and 1.5 cups water. I used molasses in the bath and it was perfect! Added onion bits, onion and garlic powder and sea salt to the tops. Baked at 475 for 10 minutes and took one out to test. Almost cooked through so baked another 5 minutes. The recipe really makes 8 good sized (not small like the frozen ones in the store) bagels. I will definitely make this recipe again.
I was using the recipe more as a baking guide than the recipe itself, and it turned out great, I used maple syrup instead of honey and my bagel bath included baking soda, salt and maple syrup.
Excellent recipe! Works perfectly by using a mix master. Video was very helpful. Thanks!

I made this recipe exactly as written. I did get 10 bagels and they were still quite large. I will make 12 next time. It did tax my Kitchenaid mixer while kneading but I kept pushing the dough down. needed about 12 minutes total of kneading. 15 Minutes in oven was perfect. I dipped them in Everything Bagel seasoning. YUM
Loved it but I found after I boiled them when they baked they came out flat.
Amazing!! They came out perfect!
Itâ€™s delicious every time

I do not have a kitchenAid or fancy beater so spent 20 minutes hand kneading the dough. I probably should have spent 30 minutes..
Besides that the bagels came out great for a first attempt and will try again when I can find a friend with a beater with dough hooks. 
Thanks for the recipe. The bagels reminded me of my time in the USA in 1995.

4 stars because I don't think the amount of oil and water was enough. I used olive and water for the required amount but wasn't enough. My dough was dry but I added some more oil and water, twice the mount of oil and about a half a cup or so more water to get the dough just right. I forgot to add the honey to the water but that was optional anyway but nevertheless it came out pretty good, the texture and taste was awesome. Thanks!

The recipe taxed my kitchen aid. I thought it was going to burn out. I had to add more water. Who k ow that mightâ€™ve watered down the flavor because it was very bland. I do not add salt to food once done and I felt like cutting the bagel open and sprinkling it inside. My carb-o-holic daughter wanted no parts of it

Easy and my family loves them. I made 6 this weekend and 8 tonight. I followed the recipe... made one though for my son who loves cinnamon raisin and came out perfect. 
Best recipe and easy
Delicious! Added a bit more salt though
Wow, awesome bagels just as good as any bakery. Some people said the dough is a bit dry so I did 1 1/2 cups water and it was spot on.

I followed the changes in the comments. I make yeast dough recipes several times a week - breads, rolls, pretzels, etc. This is not written well. You must dissolve your yeast in water and sugar first, then work into your flour. I used 4 cups of flour, which was plenty. The instructions for shaping the bagels are lacking. The final product is abysmal. Some parts are burned, some parts are still soaked from the boiling process. This is not a good recipe, even with the changes. What a waste of time and money and ingredients.
I put chocolate chips in some of them. They turned out really well although they were really tough and hard to eat. They tasted really good though.
The dough was very dry and crumbly. I had to add about 1/3 cup more water. It was working my Kitchen Aid mixer hard. But, the bagels turned out delicious!

I liked the recipe. Made it two ways. The first one was that I followed the original to which I had to add more water, about 5 Tbsp as it was much too dry. The second batch I made with some changes. After reading some of the tips of other bakers, I used a little less flour and more water and it was better. The first batch, the bagels were huge, the second I made smaller. All in all, everyone liked them especially my wife, who is my biggest critic.
Can I have knees the dough because I do not have a dough hook

Crispy, chewy bagels. The amount of flour was too much for the ratio of water resulting in a tough dough that my poor Kitchen Aid mixer just could not mix. I continued to knead the dough by hand but never got the right consistency. I made 10 bagels, 6 would be monstrous. Iâ€™ll be sure to lessen the amount of flour for the next time.
I have made this recipe a couple times. I love using Trader Joe's everything bagel spice to top off the bagels.
loved them!
My son askâ€™s for these all the time. The are a big hit at my house.
so I can't say if this recipe is good. I can tell you that the six bagels at tells you to make are monstrous
Worked well I did add a little extra water and baked for 17 min
Did it for the first time and it was perfect! Family Love it! However Iâ€™ll add additional spoon full of sugar and lesser flour next time..

The recipe was quick and easy to follow. I found the cooking time was to long and took the bagels out 5-7 minutes early or they would have burned. The first time I made them they were pretty good. The second time I made them they had risen more than expected. Once I play with the recipe and technique I think I will get them to my liking.
It turned out exceptional thank you so much for this recipe!
I used this recipe and got great results. I used AP flour instead of bread flour and I didn't add the honey. Overall it was pretty easy and my family was very happy.

First time making bagels and not an experienced baker, so this was a real adventure but have now run it three times. Dough is a bit dry and have added a bit of water each time. They are a bit large, but not outrageous. Tried it twice leaving the dough overnight and once for only two hours -- results pretty similar. Taste is great and they have the right chewiness that a bagel should have. Struggling with two things: the dough comes out a little too light, not the right bagel density, and having a little bit of trouble getting the loop to stay a loop -- the joint tends to pull/bake apart. Wetting the joint helped a bit, but still need to figure that bit out. But super easy, super tasty.

These were DELICIOUS! I followed other users' recommendations and proofed the yeast first, then I only added four cups of bread flour. It was very hard to mix (I used my hand mixer and my arm just about fell off!). I then ended up kneading it by hand for a little while on the counter. I didn't let it sit in the fridge overnight but next time I probably will. I guess I didn't roll them well enough because mine had funny stretch marks on them when they were done. Also they floated the entire time while I was boiling, and I couldn't get them to stay together where I closed the circles. I will for sure make these again and correct my mistakes, but even with the problems I had they were so good.
delicious bagels and fun to make

I'm only giving it 4 stars because even though the flavor was good and they were easy to make, everytime I boil them, they end up flat. I tried only boiling them a minute, putting them immediately into the oven, and various things people have said to do. They look great until I put them in the boiling water. Then they lose all their umph and just end up looking like a rather thick piece of bread with a crunchy crust. I don't know what I might be doing wrong.
Very good! I made 8 large bagels, next time I will split it in 10. I put shredded Asiago and cheddar cheese on top. They are amazing!!!! Not wasting money on Panera anymore lol :)
Delicious but huge! Could have made 10!
I followed the reviews and added more water . Almost double the water. The turn out was wonderful. I added cheddar cheese to mine and they were great
They were super easy and fun to make and they turned out good.
They didnâ€™t rise as much as I thought they would, but they also didnâ€™t last 5 minutes in my house. Great, easy to follow recipe.

Excellent. Great flavour and chew. Like others, I tweaked a few things. 1 tbsp sugar and 2 tbsp honey. I used regular yeast so I bloomed it in advance in the hot water, sugar and honey then added flour and salt. 3 1/2 c whole wheat bread flour and 1 c all purpose. Used about 1/2 c honey in boiling water. I put dough in fridge for about 4 hours before taking out for 2 hours and then making the bagels. When I put the bagels in boiling water, they puffed up to almost twice their size and they're huge. I made 6 very large and 4 large bagels. I would make them smaller next time and could easily get a dozen or more. Topped with sesame seed on some, poppyseed on others. Very tasty. And unlike others experienced, they didn't stick to parchment paper at all.

First attempt my shaping needs improvement however these were sooo tasty. I changed the recipe just a touch. I used 4c. all purpose flour and 1 1/2 c. water. For extra flavor I added about 2 TBS. onion powder. Will definitely make these again

Easy to make and turned out great. Perfect on first time trying. I will definitely make them again. I made 8 bagels out of the recipe vs the six they recommend. I may even go with 10 next time. They were really big.
Far too little water. After rising I had to go back and add more water and work it a lot longer. I do think these could make 8 or 9 regular size bagels as well.
A favorite. And as other reviewers have noted, 4 cups of flour is enough! I divide the dough into 8 pieces to make more "normal" sized bagels.

The 4 1/2 cups of flour the recipe calls for is too much. After reading other reviews I started with 3 cups and increased until I used 3 1/2 cups and that seems about right. I have made the recipe a few times and the bagels taste very good. Just watch the flour amount.
This recipe is a mess! There is not enough water and it is nearly impossible to mix. I am surprised it has so many good reviews. Not sure how they will work out as I just finished mixing. Oof.
They didnâ€™t stay together very well. I will make them again but, make them into sticks.
I used dark karo syrup in the water. Worked well. Also, I live at 6000 feet in Colorado Springs and didnâ€™t need to adjust the recipe. Iâ€™ve made 2 batches in 2 days and given some to neighbors.
Absolutely amazing!!! I made the dough and refrigerated it overnight (as one of the previous reviews suggested). Will definitely make this again...super yummy

I made these with a friend. Plain, onion, poppy seed, sesame seed, and everything. We did 3 batches. I thought the first dough was much too thick with the 4 cups of flour, but after kneading it for a while it was fine and turned out to be much more authentically chewy. We did two other batches with 3.5 cups of flour and they were a little lighter and still chewy. I also cut down the honey by 1/2 and it still gave the sweetness to the outside. We loved them and although a bit time consuming they were definitely worth the effort!
My first attempt at bagels-thanks to this recipe we enjoyed authentic, chewy, tasty bagels for breakfast! This recipe is a keeper!
Great recipe. Only change is to make them a little smaller for us. Thanks!
I added an extra 1/4 cup of water and it made all the difference. I also proofed my yeast before adding the flour. I was able to make 12 decent sized bagels out of one batch.

Only giving this two stars, the flavor is nice but since there is no weight for the flour it threw the hydration off. As written their is not enough water to properly hydrate the dough, I kneaded this for 25 min and never got that window pane. This recipe needs to be recalculated. Will not make again.

Delicious bagels! I realized my yeast wasn't instant so I warmed the water to lukewarm and dissolved the yeast in that. I let it sit for a couple of minutes and then added it to the dry ingredients. I made six bagel and they were a good size. We made bacon sandwiches and they were so yummy. This recipe is a keeper!
I tried to make it but it appears that something is missing from the recipe. 1 1/4 cups water will not and did not moisten 4 1/2 cups of flour.
My family loved them!
These were amazing! I will make again!

Overall, It came out great! I used the King Arthur Bread Flour and had a terrible time trying to get a windowpane, but I found online that if you let your bread sit for 15 minutes then continue to use the bread hook to knead, it'll be much easier to get a windowpane. 

I'd definitely do it again :)
Made according to directions but without the honey. I don't think we will be buying bagels anytime soon. We were very impressed with the taste and texture.
I made without a mixer. The dough was super dry and tough. When I made the bagels, the shape didnâ€™t stick.

I agree with everyone who said it didnâ€™t have much flavor. Unfortunately during this quarantine I could not get honey or malt syrup so that may make a difference. I dipped mine in salt, sundried tomato/garlic dipping mix, and everything seasoning.
Pretty tasty. Will make again.

the recipe is perfect, HIWEVER for the first timers: this is an easy recipe t get started with. Remember every time you bake your conditions will not be the same. sometimes you will need a bit more flour or water to get it the right consistency. NEVER through everything into a bowl and expect results. Add flour as needed. To those who have a baking knowledge this is old hat!!
I love this recipe, it turns out perfect every time. I di use Honey in mine, different Honey a slightly different flavor. Try buckwheat honey they will turn out as a house favorite!!
As written this recipe is a disaster. No instructions to use warm water, to start the yeast first, and the ratio of flour to water is completely off.
I used all purpose flour, it worked out great. but i only used 4 cups, very good decision. i gave to family and they already want another batch. will 100% make again :)
followed the recipe exactly except for putting yeast in warm water with some honey for about 2 mins before putting in mixture at the beginning.

You will need a touch more water than suggested, however this is a great starter recipe!!! I cut it in half, used silicone donut trays, and let them rest in the fridge overnight. They rose in the fridge and it made a perfect sized batch of six bagels. If I did the full amount I'm sure it would make a batch of twelve. I will definitely use this recipe as a base to start experimenting i.e., Olive Oil and Rosemary, Garlic/Onion, Honey Garlic, Basil Tomato.
They looked awful! The dough was really tough and I couldnâ€™t get get them to stick together. The taste was decent though.
recipe called for too much flour. Tried again only to taste bland dry bagels that were massive. Make smaller bagels and add one cup of flour at a time till dough is silky

Recipe is so simple and Easy to make. I only had regular flour and yeast . I increased the yeast by 25% as recommended on line. I used my cuisinart mixer on number 2 speed and dough was perfect. However it was getting late for the rising part so I put it in the frig overnight and got a nice slow rise! Dough handled well after I let it warm up for about an hour. I used the honey in the boiling water as directed and dipped in sesame seeds prior to baking. My only issue was how to keep the dough together on each bagel? I used a tiny bit of water and that helped but a could came apart in the boil. Any suggestions?
Good

Added Asiago cheese to the top while baking - 15 min was perfect. The dough was a bit dry, so I'd say 1 1/4 cup (plus an oz. or two) to really round out the amount of liquid needed. I added what the recipe called for initially, then gradually added small bits until the dough was just right. Loved the final bake's texture!

I followed the recipe exactly as it was written before reading reviews. The dough was way too dry. Unbelievably I was able to add about and 8th cup more water to the dough to get it to a manageable state. It rose beautifully. 
Also I think the bagels would have been much too big following the recipe for cutting them out. In the end I cut 16 pieces for 16 bagels.
If you go this small you will need to lower temp to around 400 and cook less. I actually don't really know how long I cooked mine for so I will have to play with it the next time I make them. For 16 bagels the heat is too hot and they will end up burning the ingredients on the top. For the ingredients on the top I made some garlic and onion, pizza seasoning with tomatoes and cheese, and parmesan cheese with tomato. 
Had the recipe needed no changes I would have given it 5 stars. But I feel since I had to figure out how to make some changes in order to get the dough manageable I gave it 3.
Didnâ€™t have a mixer so I kneaded it by hand for about 25 minutes

Best bagels in the world. So chewy and better than store bought. Only changes was only 1 cup of water (instead of 1 and 1/4th) and only 4 cups of flour (instead of 4 and a half). I've made this so many times!
